This like/dislike ratio genuinely frustrates me, because it raises, in me, a few questions:


Why is the inclusion of female scientists in a history course worthy of a dislike? Or, alternatively, why is pointing out the importance of non-white men in science and history problematic in the first place?


History, in all respects, scientifically, culturally, and politically, has always been a sausage fest of men stratifying others so that most accomplishments are either misattributed to those men or are simply always made claim to by men (because they were the only beings involved in the scientific process). This isn't an opinion, this is a fact. History is chauvinistic.

So, to those who disliked this video, why? Why is acknowledging the literally millennia-long neglected women-in-science deserving of a dislike? An entire half of the human species has historically been underrepresented, shunned, and removed from the scientific process via the long-held historical trend of misogyny, and somehow acknowledging this is problematic? This is half of the human species, capable of similar if not greater achievements in a field that they've rarely had the opportunity to belong to in the first place!


Do you feel like acknowledging this is unnecessary? Why would you think that? Name five male scientists and then name five female ones, or just one trans scientist. That's my point, at least, that awareness of oppressed groups contributions to both history and science ought to be taught, because the deliberate trend of historians directly glossing or ignoring them necessitates recognizing them. Science has historically been associated with men, and so has history, which is exactly why it's important to highlight non-men (or non-straight non-white non-men) in those respective sausage-fests of academic fields, simply because they haven't been associated with it for the over two thousand years those fields have existed.


Systemic academic oppression is not only real, but suppresses the importance that other people aside from men have in science and in history, and especially since those people have consistently been denied the opportunity to operate in those fields on a level playing field, the recognition of those suppressed peoples in contemporary study is not only important, it's necessary.

There is a difference in being historically underrepresented and historically under-reported. I fear the two have been conflated here. An accurate coverage of history would be expected to feature more prominently those who were dominant at the time. LET IT HAPPEN, rather than trying to cast them as villains. Then have episodes like this, or even whole series, detailing more more modern developments, which will necessarily exhibit features of a changed society. History during times dominated by men will have more men in them than women. This is not a failure of the historian. It just means we should strive to live now in such a way that future historians will not have such a representation problem.

But please, don't intentionally skew historical viewpoints. It does a disservice to your work.

One very awesome woman you didn't mention was Emmy Noether, she was a late 1800s early 1900s mathematician/physicist who brought the idea of symmetries to centre stage in physics by proving that the conservations laws we know (like conservation of energy and momentum) come from fundamental symmetries of nature (e.g. time a space translations). Her ideas are still crucial to modern day understanding of physics all the way from general relativity and cosmology and down to particle physics!

This series was awesome! Thanks, team Crash Course, for making me think about thinking with Aristotle, dig canals in Song Dynasty China, attend a music festival headlined by a robot musical band in medieval Turkey, and watch AC/DC play in NYC I mean, witness the Current War rage in New York city and witness the discovery of the shape of DNA in Cold War-era England! Could you please consider posting a bonus post/video like the 360-degree tour of the solar system in Astronomy and the list of books in Sociology? An animated gallery of all scientists (like the one in the first episode) or a list of resources for those interested in exploring the history of science even deeper would be great! Thanks again for making me unironically excited about the history (and philosophy) of science!

Also, the Social Sciences weren't touched on. My major, Linguistics has been dominated by White Men (but  one of its biggest ambassadors, John McWhorter is African-American, but I'm a white man), but sociology had a lot of its roots in African-American thinkers, such as WEB DuBois, and in one of my sociolinguistics courses, I pointed out how one of DuBois's more famous quotes could be applied to the study of African-American English, even though that falls under linguistics, and DuBois was not interested in the aspect of African-American English in African-American sociology.
And I thought we were going to make it through a modern crashcourse series without the "muh diversity" spiel. Shame.

This is the second crash course I followed till the end. I am a little disappointed that, in the history of science, we never seemed to discuss the place and relation of Science and Knowledge. Yes, this is more towards the philosophy of science which was covered in Crash Course Philosophy, but it still remains that as the so called paradigm of science changes, the nature of our understanding of the knowledge gained from that science is. For example, it is readily admitted by this video that the Newtonian Paradigm kept getting more and contradictions inside of itself and was at a point, changed by an Einsteinian Paradigm. But from this we get 2 things: 1) by simply using paradigm we are in a sense in reference to the dominant theory of Thomas Kuhn while ignoring other such theories (for example Slavoj Zizek in his work on Hegelianism poses it not as a paradigm shift but a Ptolemization of a paradigm, that in rejecting the old paradigm we keep its principle premises); and 2) as the scientific knowledge keeps expanding we seem to keep shifting to a technocracy, that is, we are forced to live unable to know but follow by example of experts on the technicalities of such things. For example on point 2), and in a sense it follows as well from point 1), we reject the Newtonian Paradigm for the Einsteinian Paradigm, but we still teach the Newtonian because it can function in these less complex matters. If I am traveling between my home (the Quad Cities of Illinois) and Chicago I know that the distance is such that with a constant velocity of 70 mph, I will reach the general area of Chicago in 2 hours. Thus, in such a case, an approximation of the distance is 140 miles.

So, all I mean to pose to crash course it that I have enjoyed the series, but with all the hope that was displayed in the metahistorical final episode, that we still face a problem that reaches deep into science itself and a problem of the philosophy of science.

Me looking at the name of the course : "I know what the like/dislike ratio will look like..."
I wasn't wrong.
